1.0    Purpose



The Purpose of this document is to describe the Fab 8 RMP Applicability for Silane and Ammonium Hydroxide.



2.0    RMP Applicability for Silane



Silane used at the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility in Saratoga County, New York and is listed as a regulated substance in 40 CFR ?68.130.  The threshold quantity for silane is 10,000 pounds.  The two isomodule trailers combined contain silane gas in the amount of approximately 26,400 pounds when full.



2.1    Silane Storage and Delivery System Engineering Controls



Silane for the Storage and Delivery System is primarily sourced from an isomodule received from TGCM.  The isomodule will be located outdoors in the silane yard area on GLOBALFOUNDRIES' property.  Silane is a compressed gas filled to a maximum pressure of 1,500 psig at 70?F.  The isomodule has eight tubes (22 inch diameter by 36 feet long) that contain a maximum of 1,650 pounds when full, totaling 13,200 lb per isomodule.  For added safety, a protective expanded-metal enclosure is provided around the tube valves and manifold piping.  The isomodule pneumatic cylinder valves and manual valves are manifolded together in the rear enclosure.  Cylinder pneumatic valves are provided on the isomodule to provide automatic tube switching and emergency shutoff capability at the source. A pneumatic valve is provided on the isomodule manifold to provide emergency shutoff capability at the source as well as local purge port capability.  Restrictive flow orifices (RFOs) are installed at the withdrawal connections on each container to prevent a worst-case downstream leak scenario.  Optical flame detectors (UV/IR monitors) are aimed at both source containers' withdrawal connections to cause a system shutdown on a flame detection alarm.  



The facility has two isomodule trailers for a maximum inventory at the site of 26,400 pounds of silane gas.  



2.2    Hazard Assessment



2.2.1    Introduction. A Hazard Assessment was conducted for GLOBALFOUNDRIES in accordance with 40

CFR 60 Subpart B.  The Hazard Assessment consists of the following tasks:



?    worst-case release scenario analysis

?    alternative release scenario analysis

?    defining off-site impacts - population and environmental receptors

?    five-year accident history



The GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility currently uses silane, which is on the list of regulated flammable substances (40 CFR Part 68.130). The flammable endpoint for silane is 1 pound per square inch (psi) overpressure.  



2.2.2        Worst-Case Release Scenario Description.  The worst-case release scenario is defined as the "release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint" [40 CFR Part 68.25].  The "endpoint" or "flammable endpoint" of a substance is defined as the distance a toxic vapor cloud, fire, or explosion from an accidental release will travel before dissipating to the point that serious injuries from short-term exposures will no longer occur. The Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance provided by the USEPA recommends that the worst-case release scenario be based on the following:



1.    Failure of the single biggest vessel holding silane, leading to an airborne release of the entire inventory.



2.    The release rate is the total inventory uniformly distributed over 10 minutes.



3.    The meteorological conditions at the time of the release are characterized by a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s), an ambient temperature of   77?F (25?C), and an atmospheric stability class F.



4.    Passive mitigation systems may be included in the analysis (if applicable).



The worst-case release scenario is defined as a release of silane from an entire tube (22 inch diameter by 36 feet long) from the eight tube module.  Specifically, this scenario results in a release of the entire contents 1654 lbs (750 kg) of a single module vessel during a catastrophic failure. The contents of the vessel form a vapor cloud followed by a delayed ignition resulting in a vapor cloud

explosion. The hazard assessment guideline of RMP requires the worst case release results include a vapor cloud containing the total quantity of the substance that could be released from a vessel.  



No passive mitigation measures (e.g., berms, and dikes) were considered as part of this worst-case release scenario. 



2.2.3        Alternative Release Scenario Description.  The alternative release scenario [40 CFR Part 68.28] is considered the most likely release to occur from a covered process that is expected to produce the greatest distance to a flammable endpoint.  The Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance provided by the USEPA recommends that the alternative release scenario be based on the following:



1.    The scenario most likely to occur.



2.    The meteorological conditions at the time of the release are characterized by a wind speed of 3 meters per second (m/s), an ambient temperature of 77?F (25?C), and an atmospheric stability class D.



3.    Active as well as passive mitigation systems may be included in the analysis (if applicable).



The alternative release scenario most likely to cause off-site consequences is a release of the entire contents of a single module vessel during a catastrophic failure of the vessel primary delivery valve. The valve is a mechanically assembled component which fails and the top works of the valve is removed from the base of the valve.  In this scenario, a 0.157 inch diameter hole remains in the base of the valve and limits the release rate from the vessel.  



As with the worst-case release scenario, no passive mitigation measures (e.g., berms, and dikes) or active mitigation measures were considered as part of this alternative release scenario. 

 

2.2.4        Off-Site Consequence Analysis.  The off-site consequence analysis considers the effects of the worst-case and the alternative release scenarios on off-site areas.  The off-site area considered is a circle with its center at the release point and radius equal to the d

istance to the flammable endpoints.  For both the worst-case and the alternative release scenarios, the effected population is evaluated and public and environmental receptors are determined.  



1.    Off-Site Consequence Analysis - Worst-Case Release Scenario.  The total affected area for the worst-case release scenario is approximately 0.025 mi2 (475 feet release radius).  Based on this scenario, there are no affected public receptors, which can include residences, schools, churches, and public recreation areas.  There are no environmental receptors within the vulnerable zone.



2.    Off-Site Consequence Analysis - Alternative Release Scenario.  The total affected area for the alternative release scenario is approximately 0.01 mi2 (317 feet release radius).  Based on this scenario, there are no affected public receptors, which can include residences, schools, churches, and public recreation areas.  There are no environmental receptors within the vulnerable zone.





2.3    RMP Program Level Determination



The USEPA regulations assigned three different levels of complexity to the RMP program, depending on certain criteria at the particular plant in question.  The GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility qualifies as "Program 1" plant based on several factors.  Specifically, the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility is eligible for Program 1 because there are no public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a worst-case release; the process has had no release of a regulated substance (silane) in the past five years where exposure to the substance has resulted in one or more offsite deaths, injuries, or response/restoration activities for exposure to an environmental receptor; and the facility has coordinated their emergency response activities with the local responders.  



3.0    RMP Applicability for Ammonium Hydroxide



Ammonium Hydroxide used at the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility in the Malta, New York is listed as a regulated substance in 40 CFR ?68.130.  The threshold quantity for ammon

ium hydroxide at concentrations greater than 20% is 20,000 pounds.  The two 25,000 liter storage tanks, located in Fab 8 Extension contain approximately 28,710 pounds of ammonium hydroxide in total when full.



3.1    Ammonium Hydroxide Storage and Delivery System Process Description



Ammonium hydroxide is off-loaded from 19,100-liter capacity tanker trucks into two interconnected 25,000-liter storage tanks, located in the chemical storage room within the Fab 8 Extension Building (near the northeast corner of building).  The secondary containment system for the ammonium hydroxide off-loading activities is approximately 3,875 liters in .  In the event of a spill during unloading operations, the ammonium hydroxide would be contained with the trenches of the secondary containment system.



The chemical storage room within the Fab 8 Extension Building is ventilated/exhausted through a roof mounted sulfuric acid scrubber with a minimum of 90% control efficiency.



3.2    Hazard Assessment



3.2.1    Introduction. A Hazard Assessment was conducted for the GLOBALFOUNDRIES in accordance with 40 CFR 60 Subpart B.  The Hazard Assessment consists of the following tasks:



?    worst-case release scenario analysis

?    alternative release scenario analysis

?    defining off-site impacts - population and environmental receptors

?    five-year accident history



The GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility currently uses 29% ammonium hydroxide solution, which is on the list of regulated flammable substances (40 CFR Part 68.130). The toxic endpoint for concentrations of ammonium hydroxide greater than 20% is 0.14 mg/L. 



3.2.2        Worst-Case Release Scenario Analysis.  The worst-case release scenario is defined as the "release scenario that is estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint" [40 CFR Part 68.25].  The "endpoint" or "toxic endpoint" of a substance is defined as "the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals can be exposed f

or up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action" [USEPA, 1998].  The Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance provided by the USEPA recommends that the worst-case release scenario be based on the following:



1.    Failure of the entire contents of an ammonium hydroxide tanker truck, which has a maximum capacity of 19,100 liters, during off-loading activities leading to an airborne release of the entire inventory directly to atmosphere.



2.    The release rate is the total inventory uniformly distributed over 10 minutes.



3.    The meteorological conditions at the time of the release are characterized by a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second (m/s), an ambient temperature of 77?F (25?C), and an atmospheric stability class F.



4.    Passive mitigation systems may be included in the analysis (if applicable).



The worst-case release scenario is defined as a release of 29% ammonium hydroxide solution from a delivery tanker truck during outdoor off-loading operations, where the entire contents of the 19,100-liter tanker truck is released.  The spilled ammonium hydroxide, from a tanker truck hose rupture or pump failure, for example, would be directed to the secondary containment system for the off-loading activities, which consists of a grated trench system.  The spilled materials are ultimately pumped out of the trench system for proper handling and disposal. 



Passive mitigation measures (e.g., secondary containment trench system) were considered as part of this worst-case release scenario. 



3.2.3        Alternative Release Scenario Analysis.  The alternative release scenario [40 CFR Part 68.28] is considered the most likely release to occur from a covered process that is expected to produce the greatest distance to a toxic endpoint.  The Off-Site Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance provided by the USEPA recommends that the alternative relea

se scenario be based on the following:



1.    The scenario most likely to occur.



2.    The meteorological conditions at the time of the release are characterized by a wind speed of 3 meters per second (m/s), an ambient temperature of 77?F (25?C), and an atmospheric stability class D.



3.    Active as well as passive mitigation systems may be included in the analysis (if applicable).



The alternative release scenario most likely to cause off-site consequences is a release of the entire contents of a single 25,000-liter ammonium hydroxide storage tank, which is located within the chemical storage room of the Fab 8 Extension Building.  A catastrophic release from the 25,000-liter storage tank would be contained within the secondary containment system for the ammonium hydroxide storage tanks.  The vapor emissions from the spilled ammonium hydroxide would be ventilated and exhausted through a sulfuric acid scrubber with a minimum of 90% removal efficiency before entering the atmosphere.  



The active mitigation measures of venting ammonium hydroxide emissions through the acid scrubber were considered as part of this alternative release scenario. 

 

3.2.4        Off-Site Consequence Analysis.  The off-site consequence analysis considers the effects of the worst-case and the alternative release scenarios on off-site areas.  The off-site area considered is a circle with its center at the release point and radius equal to the distance to the toxic endpoints.  For both the worst-case and the alternative release scenarios, the effected population is evaluated and public and environmental receptors are determined.  



1.    Off-Site Consequence Analysis - Worst-Case Release Scenario.  The total affected area for the worst-case release scenario is approximately 0.28 mi2 (0.3 miles release radius).  Based on this scenario, there are no affected public receptors, which can include residences, schools, churches, and public recreation areas.  There are no environmental receptors within

the vulnerable zone.



2.    Off-Site Consequence Analysis - Alternative Release Scenario.  The total affected area for the alternative release scenario is less than 0.03 mi2 (<0.1 miles release radius).  Based on this scenario, there are no affected public receptors, which can include residences, schools, churches, and public recreation areas.  There are no environmental receptors within the vulnerable zone.



3.3    RMP Program Level Determination



The USEPA regulations assigned three different levels of complexity to the RMP program, depending on certain criteria at the particular plant in question.  The GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility qualifies as "Program 1" plant based on several factors.  Specifically, the GLOBALFOUNDRIES facility is eligible for Program 1 because there are no public receptors within the distance to an endpoint from a worst-case release; the process has had no release of a regulated substance (29% ammonium hydroxide) in the past five years where exposure to the substance has resulted in one or more offsite deaths, injuries, or response/restoration activities for exposure to an environmental receptor; and the facility has coordinated their emergency response activities with the local responders.
